34 Joyful Things To Do In Bhutan In 2025 For A Mesmerising Experience

..
SHARES
Updated Date: 20 January 2025

Trekking to sublime mountains, exploring the colorful villages, meditating inside the peaceful monasteries, and learning the history of the dzongs—there are plenty of things to do in Bhutan that are sure to leave you mesmerized. Tourists flocking to the happiest country in the world are lured by its natural beauty, old monasteries, its colourful festivals, and warm Bhutanese hospitality. So, are you ready for the ultimate things that you can do in Bhutan? Let’s dive in!


Table Of Content

34 Things To Do In Bhutan

India’s beautiful neighbouring country has something for all; it attracts families, friends, and hundreds of bikers and solo travellers every year. Bhutan is a rare place on Earth, and one can hardly see any signs of commercialization, but it is a perfect place to visit. And it is primarily because, for travellers, there is no shortage of places to see and things to do in Bhutan.

    • Taktsang Goemba (Tiger’s Nest) – Go For A Trek

1. Taktsang Goemba (Tiger’s Nest) – Go For A Trek

The trek to Taktsang monastery in Paro, popularly called the Tiger’s Nest, is one of the best adventure activities in Bhutan. After being destroyed by fire, the monastery was rebuilt in 1998. Rising 9480 ft above the ground, it challenges the trekkers to walk the rocky winding path. Taktsang Cafeteria is the only rest point offering lip-smacking vegetarian Bhutanese food. The colourful prayer flags, the rattling sounds of prayer wheels, the view of Paro Valley, and the calming chants will accompany you throughout the trek. Remember to start your trek early as the monastery closes at 1:00 pm. So, while preparing the list of things to do in Bhutan, don’t miss to include this gem for an additional dose of thrill to your trip.

Location: Paro, Bhutan

Timings: 8 AM to 1 PM and 2 PM to 6 PM

Duration: 3-4 hours

Entry Fee: 2,000 Nu

Highlight: Enjoy a mesmerising time amidst the most gorgeous landscape

Also Read: Bhutan In March

2. Trongsa Dzong – Dig Into Bhutan’s History

If you love to explore historical places, then Trongsa Dzong – the ancestral home of the Royal Family is one of the best tourist places in Bhutan. Built approximately 463 years ago during Trongsa Penlop Chogyal Minjur Tempa, the fortress boasts a great location overlooking the Mangde River. Also, it has witnessed many major events that have shaped the kingdom’s history. As you wander through Trongsa Dzong, don’t miss visiting its 24 chapels and the museum in the watchtower. The street-like corridors, beautiful courtyards, and stone stairs tell you the tales of bygone times. Known for its incredible printery that is used to produce religious text, this place holds great religious significance. It attracts tourists from all over the world to witness its unique charm.

Location: FGX3+VXG, Trongsa, Bhutan

Timing: 6 AM to 5 PM

Duration: 2-3 hours

Entry Fee: 200 Nu

Highlights: Explore street-like corridors, courtyards and stone stairs

3. Bumthang Valley – Explore The Switzerland Of East


Among the best things to do in Bhutan is to take the Bumthang Cultural Trek and explore much more than the beauty of the Bumthang valley. The cultural trek offers picturesque views of the monasteries, temples, and quaint villages. You also get to explore the beautiful villages and experience great hospitality. Until the 1970s, the area was only accessible by muddy trails and mules. Ura Valley is another place lost in the mist of time in Bumthang. Quaint villages with clustered houses, potato fields, and sheep pastures. This is the kind of valley where you can go on a photo walk. Besides the breathtaking mountains and natural beauty, Bumthang valley is blessed with some of the oldest Buddhist temples in Bhutan. It is also the place where Buddhism was first introduced and where saint Pema Lingpa was born.

Location: Central Bhutan, in the Bumthang district

Timings: Open all day

Duration: 3 days

Entry Fee: Free

Highlights: Enjoy scenic views and explore this spiritual hreatland

Related Post: Bhutan In August

4. Trashiyangtse – Hike To This Heavenly Place


If nature mesmerizes you, a visit to Trashiyangtse is going to be captivating, to say the least. Born out of Trashigang district in 1992 as a separate district, it sits in the middle of a small river valley, making it an ideal place for long, refreshing walks in the countryside. Another one of the best things to do in Bhutan is explore one of the most important stupas – Chorten Kora, situated next to the Kulong Chu River in Trashiyangtse. Trashiyangtse is also a starting point for hikes to nature reserves, paper workshops, wood carving, and monasteries. If you’re interested in bird-watching nearby, then a long walk to Bomdeling Wildlife Sanctuary, which is home to Black-necked Cranes that migrate from Tibet in winter. Bomdeling is also popular for its brilliant woodcraft.

Location: Transhitangtse District, Bhutan

Timings: 6 AM to 7 PM

Duration: 2-3 hours

Entry fee: Free

Highlights: Hikes to nature reserves, paper workshops, wood carving, and monasteries

5. Wildlife Sanctuaries – Go For Bird Watching


The kingdom of Bhutan is a paradise for bird lovers, and bird-watching is one of the most popular Bhutan attractions. The country harbours many species of birds, including the Himalayan Monal, Rufous-necked Hornbill, Black-necked Crane, Ward’s Trogon, and Snow Pigeon. It is beautiful to listen to the music of birds and see them soar high in the sky, spreading those colorful, smooth wings. There are many tour guides around the sanctuaries to take you on a bird-watching tour. Bumdeling Wildlife Sanctuary, Jigme Dorji National Park, Jigme Singye Wangchuck National Park, Adjoining India’s World Heritage, and Thrumshingla National Parks are some of the protected areas in Bhutan where you can also find migrating and endangered birds.

Location: RP9H+M2P, Gasa, Bhutan (Jigme Dorji National Park)

Timings: 9 AM to 5 PM

Duration: 3-4 hours

Entry fee: 150 Nu

Highlights: Explore wildlife adventure for a mesmerising trip

Related Post: Bhutan In April

6. Punakha & Semtokha Dzongs – See Ancient Art Come To Life

Bhutan focuses on preserving its culture, and art is a major part of that culture. Bhutanese art is based on its religion and follows a uniform style. The crafts follow traditional values rather than emphasizing innovation. The importance of Bhutanese culture lies in their art and craft. To witness the beautiful art and craft, you must tour the kingdom’s different dzongs, including Punakha Dzong and Semtokha Dzong. A DIY art and craft tour is among the best things to do in Bhutan for every art lover. Flaunting its historical charm and architectural wonders, Punakha Dzong is a crowd-puller and is counted among the top tourist places in Bhutan. Here, you can also capture countless instaworthy pictures alongside the river at many places to visit in Punakha.

Location: HVJ7+V6Q, Bhutan

Timings: 9 AM to 5 PM (Summers) and 11 AM to 1 PM, 3 PM to 5 PM (Winters)

Duration: 2-3 hours

Entry fee: 300 Nu

Highlights: Dzongs are symbolic centers of religious and secular affairs

7. The Memorial Stupa – Rediscover Yourself


If you want to get lost in the realm of peace, then head to The Memorial Stupa built in 1974 in the memory of the third king, Jigme Dorji Wangchuck. The place is also known as the name of Thimphu Chorten and captures the attention of history buffs from all over the world. Representing world peace and honour, the Stupa holds a special place in the hearts of the people of the nation. The Memorial Stupa is counted among the most visited sites of Bhutan and features many exciting things such as a photo of the Druk Gyalpo in a ceremonial dress. The stupa is one of the best Bhutan attractions with its shining finial, beautifully carved sculptures of deities, vivid paintings, and ultimate peace. Some hermits and devoted Buddhists often walk into the mountains for months to meditate.

Location: Memorial Stupa, Thimphu, Bhutan

Timings: 5 AM to 8 PM

Duration: 2-3 hours

Entry fee: Free

Highlights: Explore its shining finial, beautifully carved sculptures of deities, vivid paintings, and ultimate peace

Related Post: Bhutan In June

8. Bhutanese Cuisine – Relish The Delicacies

When we think of Bhutan, we generally imagine varieties of non-veg food offered in small & cozy cafes. While it’s true that you get various types of non-veg cuisine, there are also plenty of options for vegetarians—for instance, Datshi – a staple food of the people of Bhutan. Datshi is made in various forms and the most famous is Ema Datshi. Ema means chilli; Ema Datshi is made using cheese, chillies, vegetables, and pepper. Folk Heritage Museum Restaurant (Thimphu), Zombala, Bukhari at Uma by COMO (Paro), Ambient Cafe (Thimphu), Galingkha (Thimphu), and Chig-ja-gye at Taj Tashi (Thimphu) are some of the best restaurants in Bhutan to try different flavours and textures of Bhutanese food. A local food tour is amongst the best things to do in Bhutan and is highly recommended.

Location: Zombala Restaurant, Folk Heritage Museum Restaurant, Ambient Cafe

Timings: Varies from Restaurant to Restaurant

Duration: NA

Entry Fee: NA

Highlights: Must try food is Ema Datshi, Kewa Datshi, Momos, Jasha Maru and Ara

9. Shopping – Explore The Local Stores Of Bhutan


Norzin Lam is the city’s major thoroughfare lined with hotels, cafes, stalls, and shops. It’s one of the best places to shop in Bhutan. You can get everything from embroidered boots to handmade papers. Some of the good things to buy in Bhutan include carpets, silver, colorful masks, jewelry, hand-woven bamboo items, and wooden products. The lively market offers a wonderful photo opportunity to tourists, explorers, and photographers. Flaunting its vibrant atmosphere and local culture, it is one of the best places in Bhutan where you can indulge in the real essence of Bhutan. Explore variety of goods, including textiles, scarves and craft stalls and have a delightful shopping experience with Bhutan famous things to buy. Although there are countless markets in Bhutan but Norzim Lam is the most famous spot for shoppaholics.

Location: Norzin Lam 1, Thimphu, Bhutan

Timings: 10 AM to 3 PM, Closed on Tuesday

Duration: 4-5 hours

Entry Fee: NA

Highlights: Explore variety of goods, including textiles, scarves and craft stalls and have a delightful shopping experience

Related Post: Things To Buy In Bhutan

10. Changlimithang Archery Ground – Try Archery


If you are in Bhutan, you must attend the archery competitions, which are one of the best Bhutan attractions and its national sport, too. While strolling the highways and byways of Bhutan, you’ll find colourful gatherings of men dressed in their traditional robes, taking turns to shoot arrows. The archery competitions draw many people to this social event, and competitions are organized between towns, villages, and amateur teams. It’s a fantastic glimpse into their culture. Archery is a traditional martial art in Bhutanese culture and is an immersive experience to have in Bhutan. You can also take the help of professionals if you are trying it for the first time. So, while preparing the list of things to do in Bhutan, don’t forget to include this gem in your list.

Location: Bigsa Archery Gallery, Chang Lam SE, Thimphu, Bhutan

Timings: 7.30 AM to 11 AM

Duration: 2-3 hours

Entry fee: Free

Highlights: Enjoy traditional martial art for Changlimithang Archery

11. River Rafting – Treat Your Adventurous Soul

Unlike the regular river rafting in strong currents, rafting in Bhutan is a pleasurable ride while floating down the river. You will marvel at the lush greenery, rare birds, clear skies, and blue waters of Bhutan. The best time to do this activity is after the monsoon season as the flow of water increases. Thus, you can plan a vacation in October or November. River rafting is a perfect thing to do in Bhutan along with enjoying its stunning scenery, thrilling rapids and cultural immersion. You can also marvel at the breathtaking views of valleys, waterfalls, and the Punakha Dzong. Counted among the must-try adventure sports in Bhutan, there are many locations where you can enjoy this sport to its fullest.

Location: Po Chu River and Mo Chu River

Timings: Daytime

Duration: 2-3 hours

Entry Fee: River rafting charges

Highlights: Marvel at the breathtaking views of valleys, waterfalls, and the Punakha Dzong

Related Post: Valleys In Bhutan

12. Kayaking – Try A New Adventure

Bhutan not only gives a chance to indulge in whitewater river rafting but also offers travelers to opt for kayaking. Six rivers in Bhutan give ample opportunity to water sports enthusiasts and amateur kayakers. You can opt for what kind of current flow you want from slow to violent. Loaded with six major rivers, Bhutan offer a delightful experience of Kayaking for all the thrill seekers. If you are looking for adventure and tranquility at the same time, then Kayaking in Bhutan is a great experience for you. Flaunting its spiritual mountainous land and cultural heritage, it is a perfect spot for a vacation with family and friends.

Location: Near Paro Valley and Punakha Valley

Timings: Daytime

Duration: March-April, October, November

Entry fee: Kayaking fee

Highlights: Explore its spiritual mountainous land and cultural heritage during Kayaking

13. Suspension Bridge – Capture Postcard-Worthy Images

Near Punakha Dzong, you will get to witness the beauty of one of the longest suspension bridges in Bhutan. Encircled by the mountains of Bhutan, the whole setting of the suspension bridge is captivating for any nature lover. You will be surprised to know that the bridge does not shake even a little despite being such a long bridge. Known for its aesthetic structure, the Suspension Bridge in Punakha offers breathtaking vistas of surrounding valleys and mountains and leaves visitors in awe. The main attraction of the bridge is that it is adorned with colourful Buddhist prayer flags and offers an immersive insight into the local culture. Counted among the most iconic landmarks, it is located in close proximity to Punakha Dzong and is one of the must-visit places in Bhutan.

Location: Punakha, Bhutan

Timings: Daytime

Duration: 3-4 hours

Entry fee: Free

Highlights: The Suspension Bridge in Punakha offers breathtaking vistas of surrounding valleys and mountains

 

Related Post: Trekking In Bhutan

14. Wildlife Safari – Explore The Wildlife Of Bhutan

Bhutan is one of the splendid places to witness the biodiversity in Asia. The thick forests of Bhutan give a chance to see an amalgamation of flora and fauna. You will get to see black bears, golden langurs, Asiatic lion, tigers, and various birds. You can opt for a wildlife safari to get a better view of these animals without tiring. To witness a great wildlife adventure, you can visit WCNP in Bhutan which is the largest wildlife sanctuary is a perfect place to land for wildlife lovers. Here, you can have a close encounter with wildlife animals, as well as indulge in wildlife photography. So, if you are looking for some adventurous experience then it is a great place to plan your trip.

Location: Forests of Mo Chhu River

Timings: Daytime

Duration: April-June, September-November

Entry fee: NA

Highlights: Wildlife adventure and photography

15. Fishing – Go Catch Them

This might come as a surprise to you but Bhutan is also known for fishing as it is home to a number of species of fishes. The two most common types of fishes here are brown trout and snow trout. While exploring Bhutan, you can get a permit for fishing and go to one of the fishing spots. There are many rivers where you can indulge in fishing experience in Bhutan. For the fishing in each river, you need to get a separate permit and a certified fishing guide. On some special occasions and holidays, as well as during spawning seasons, there are some restrictions on fishing. Some common species of fishes that you can found in Bhutan are brown trout, snow trout, catfish and golden mahseer.

Location: Thimpu Valley, Bumthang Valleys, and Paro Valley

Timings: Daytime

Duration: March-May, September-November

Entry fee: NA

Highlights: Enjoy fishing experience at many rivers in Bhutan

Related Post: Indian Restaurants In Bhutan 

16. Mountain Motorbiking – The Adventure Ride

Image Credits: Wikipedia

Bhutan is blessed with valleys, mountains, and well-maintained roads. With that being said, mountain biking is the most preferred adventure activity in Bhutan. If you are planning to ride solo, then do accompany yourself with a guide. If you are a group, then you should know more about motorbiking in a foreign country. Either way, mountain motorbiking in Bhutan is a supreme experience that will let you explore the heights of this magical world, give you a glimpse of the flora and fauna, and taste the amazing local cuisine. Some amazing places for motorbiking include Punakha Valley, Phobjikha Valley, Khotokha Valley, Dobji Dzong and so much more.

Location: Paro Valley, and Punakha Valley

Timings: NA

Duration: 3-4 hours

Entry fee: 8396.67 Nu

Highlights: Mountain motorbiking in Bhutan is a supreme experience that will let you explore the heights of this magical world

17. Attend Festivals – Get Acquainted With Culture

Image Credit: Stephen Shephard for Wikimedia Commons

Wondering what to see in Bhutan? It becomes a great pleasure if you get to learn about a country’s culture through their festivals. So, one of the top Bhutan travel tips that we can provide is to explore the festivals in Bhutan that are a great celebration of the heritage and culture. Bhutan is a Buddhist state, and the festivals are a combination of vibrancy, happiness and richness that let you explore the country in a unique way. Wouldn’t you agree that this is one of the top things to do in Bhutan for cultural exploration? Several major Bhutanese festivals are Thimphu Tsechu Festival, Haa Summer Festival, Matsutake Festival, Ura Yakchoe, Jomolhari Mountain Festival, and so much more.

Location: Different places of Bhutan

Timings: Varies from festival to featival

Durations: Varies from festival to featival

Entry Fee: NA

Highlights: Explore the combination of vibrancy, happiness and richness

Related Post: Street Food In Bhutan

18. Visit The Rinpung Dzong – Gather Spiritual Greatness

Image Credit: Bernard Gagnon for Wikimedia Commons

The Rinpung Dzong is a large Buddhist monastery and fortress in the Paro district of Bhutan. If you are wondering about what to do in Bhutan, then this Dzong is the perfect place to be. Built in 1646, the literal conversion of the Dzong’s name means ‘the Fortress on a heap of Jewels’. The grand, harmonious and elegant structure overlooking the Paro valley charges you with a great sense of spirituality. You can see some amazing things at the Dzong like the sacred Thogdel, the prayer hall with amazing murals, the intricate wooden designs of the walls and panoramic views of the Paro valley. The valley has a beautiful town and with multiple Dzongs which you can plan to spend on at least a 3 to 4 day trip to Paro. You can also plan to stay humbly at some of the best homestays in Paro. 

Location: Paro, Bhutan

Timings: 7 AM to 5.30 PM

Duration: 3-4 hours

Entry fee: 500 Nu

Highlights: Explore sacred Thogdel, the prayer hall with amazing murals, the intricate wooden designs of the walls and panoramic views of the Paro valley.

19. Dochula Pass – An Auspicious Destination

Image Credit: Afifa Afrin for Wikimedia Commons

Located at an elevation of 3,100 metres from the sea level, the Dochula Pass in Bhutan is a mountain pass located on the road between Thimpu and Punakha. Visiting here for a trek or hike can be one of the best things to do in Bhutan, considering the fact that you are an adventure freak. You will find the auspicious 108 memorial chortens also known as “Druk Wangyal Chortens”.  Some of the top reasons to visit the Dochula Pass are the 360-degree view of Himalayas, especially the   Gangkar Puensum, which is the highest peak in Bhutan and the pass being one of the most beautiful passes in the world. Some other amazing attractions that you can find are the Druk Wangyal Lhakhang temple and Bhutan’s first Royal Botanical Park. 

Location: East-West Road from Thimphu to Punakha

Timings: Daylight hours

Duration: 3-4 hours

Entry fee: Free

Highlights: A stunning mountain pass to enjoy scenic views and pleasant weather.

 

Related Post: Architecture In Bhutan

20. Camping – Make Those Tents

Image Source: Pexels

It is no wonder that Bhutan is beautiful, serene and one of the most quaint destinations. Therefore, with a herd of destinations, camping is one of the best activities to do in Bhutan to get a sense of the scenery around. Imagine a bonfire under the pleasant sunset, local music, food and your loved one sitting right by your side. With a lovely set of rivers flowing around, fishing and boating is another crazy adventure you can hop onto while camping in Bhutan.Some of the top sites where you can enjoy all the pleasures of camping in Bhutan are Phobjikha Falls, Bumthang valley, Punakha, Limukha, Tingtibi and Gangtey valley. So, with such auspicious locations, where are you planning your camp?

Best Spot: Punakha, Gangtey, Lhuentse. Tingtibi, Khotokha

Timings: 24 hours

Duration: 1-2 days

Entry fee: NA

Highlight: Enjoy the pleasant sunset, local music, and food while camping in Bhutan

 

21. Cycling – Hustle To Perfection

Image Source: Pxhere

Visiting Bhutan or not, cycling is a great recreational thing to do. While you are on a trip to Bhutan, the mysterious land of valleys, rivers and mountains, naturally, exploring it through two wheels is an experience of a lifetime. You can visit Bhutan for the endless amount of Himalayan roads, clear air and Buddhist temples that stretch from one corner of the country to another. Cycling in Bhutan is a refreshing task as your journey takes you through twisting roads, passes, ravines that eventually lead to a quaint town.  The best places to enjoy one of the challenging activities to do in Bhutan are the valleys, especially Paro, Jigme Dorji National Park, Punakha and Thimphu. Some amazing routes for cycling that let you witness beautiful scenes are Thimphu to Jangchhub Lam, Haa to Paro, Thimphu to Yandren Lam and so much more.

Best Spots: Paro Valley, Punakha Valley, and Bumthang Valley

Timings: Daytime

Duration: 4-5 hours

Entry fee: NA

Highlights: Enjoy sightseeing of the endless amount of Himalayan roads, clear air and Buddhist temples.

Related Post: Backpacking In Bhutan

22. Enjoy The Hot Springs – For Ultimate Wellness

Image Credit: Chuck Moravec for Wikimedia Commons

The hot springs have been pivoted as a popular wellness therapy solution by the locals for centuries. So, you, as a tourist can get to experience this treatment for a soulful rejuvenation. The local name for these hot springs are Tshachus with medicinal properties that cure ailments like arthritis and body aches. It is a well-known tradition for the locals to enjoy hot spring dips during the winter months. One of the top things to do in Bhutan, you must note that you need to properly research and verify about the natural health therapy before proceeding to these hot springs. Some hot springs in Bhutan provide amazing views of the surroundings, located near the river banks like at Gasa Tshachu, Dhur Tshachu, Chuboog Tshachu and Duenmang Tshachu.

Best Spots: Gasa Tshachu, Duenmang Tshachu, Gelephu Tshachu

Timings: 9 AM to 10 PM

Duration: 2-3 hours

Entry fee: Free

Highlights: Experience this well-known tradition and enjoy hot spring dips

23. Horse Riding – Ride Through A Grand Journey

Image Source: Pxhere

Well are you wondering about what to do in Bhutan, now that you have gone through this crazy list. Well, you will experience the best of tracks and some fabulous places on your way if you choose to ride horses in Bhutan. There are some grand Himalayan trails that cover the ancient trade routes, lakes, mountains and some picture-perfect destinations.  An important and popular riding path is the Druk Path Trekking route that is covered between Paro and Thimpu. This is a go-to adventure and a unique thing to do in Bhutan riding on Yueta horses along the royal trails of the country. You might get to see some popular attractions like the Taktshang Goemba, Punakha Dzong and Drukgyel Dzong, if you are lucky enough.

Best Spots: Paro and Thimphu

Timings: Daytime

Duration: 3-4 hours

Entry fee: NA

Highlights: Enjoy horse-riding to add some thrill in your trip

 

Related Post: Monasteries In Bhutan

24. Tour The Museums – Learn More About Culture

Image Credit: Bernard Gagnon for Wikimedia Commons 

One of the top things to do in Bhutan is understanding and learning the grand heritage that the country is. And a tour to the several museums is a perfect way to do it. Witness through the struggles of the people by going through their past tradition, history and religion. For the culture aficionados, exploring museums in Bhutan is a great pastime. Some amazing museums that inspire the culture enthusiast in you are the National Museum of Bhutan, the National Textile Museum and the Folk Heritage Museum. You can also visit Simply Bhutan, Bhutan Postal Museum, Royal Heritage Museum and National Handicraft Emporium.

Best Spots: National Museum, Royal Textile Academy of Bhutan, National Folk Heritage Museum

Timings: Daytime

Duration: 3-4 hours

Entry fee: Varies from Museum to Museum

Highlights: Explore the rich culture and heritage of Museum

25. Haa Valley – Hike Through Dense Forests

Image Credit: Greenmnm69 for Wikimedia Commons 

Visited monasteries, went for a camp, attended the festivals and still wondering about what to do in Bhutan? It is normal to feel that way but here enters Haa Valley, a sweet sensation in the country of Bhutan. A gorgeous landscape nestled between the hills, hiking in Bhutan is not complete without a trip to Haa Valley. While hiking, you will come across some amazing Buddhist temples, the Haa Chu riverbed and a plantation trail in the valley. You can plan for a 7-8 day trip and stay at some amazing guest houses, resorts and lodges that nestle in this peaceful valley. The hike will pass through some glorious views of Paro and Haa. Apart from adventure, you are also acquainted with cultural touring within your trek.

Location: Haa Valley, Haa, Bhutan

Timings: 24 hours

Duration: 3-4 hours

Entry fee: Free

Highlights: Enjoy scenic views and hiking passing through some glorious views of Paro and Haa

Related Post: Bhutan In Autumn

26. Trek To Dagala Trail – A Beautiful Place

Image Credit: Zoepa for Wikimedia Commons

One of the best things to do in Bhutan is to trek in the Dagala Lake trail. Adorned with pristine and crystal clear lakes, you will walk across stunning views of the Himalayan mountains. The trek will also take you through some amazing Bhutanese villages where you can get the idea of traditional Bhutanese life. It is a tedious trek but the amazing landscape makes up for it. The trek is little challenging hence the perfect spot for adventurous seekers to quench their thrill thrist. Here, you can enjoy some extra dose of adventure, as well as enjoy scenic views of high-altitude lakes, alpine flora and birdwatching. Along with revel this moderate-level hiking, you can also bask in the wonderful sightseeing of Thimphu’s attractions.

Location: Genekha Village, Thimphu

Timings: Daytime

Duration: 5-6 days

Entry fee: None

Highlights: The trek will also take you through some amazing Bhutanese villages where you can get an idea of traditional Bhutanese life.

27. Rock Climbing – An Adventure Of A Lifetime

Image Source: Pexels

Another adventurous journey that you can do while enjoying a vacation in Bhutan is rock climbing. It might not top the list of best things to do in Bhutan, but for adventure seekers, it is surely a soulful sojourn. However, this task is not meant for everyone but those with physical strength and an active mindset. There are many routes and spots where you can enjoy rock climbing and add an extra dose of adventure to your trip. You can also join training sessions and climbing sessions if you are a begginner and want to learn about rock climbing. Bhutan is inviting climbing enthusiasts since early 1998. 

Location: Paro, Punakha, Trongsa and Jakar

Timings: Daytime

Duration: 3-4 hours

Entry fee: Depends on operator

Highlights: Enjoy soulful sojourn of rock climbing in Bhutan

Related Post: Zangtopelri In Bhutan

28. Bird Watching – Explore The Rich Fauna

Image Credit: Francesco Veronesi for Wikimedia Commons

One of the most relaxing things to do in Bhutan is Bird Watching. Bhutan is home to a lot of national parks and sanctuaries. The landscape is full of an amazing collection of flora and fauna and so bird watching becomes an utmost enjoyable experience while in Bhutan. Flaunting its most scenic natural landscapes, Bhutan is among the best places where you can enjoy birdwatching. Its evergreen area are perfect to attract birds and offer a delightful birdwatching experience to visitors. There are many spots to enjoy birdwatching in Bhutan including Semgang, Phobjikha, Tingbitti, Yongola, Trongsa and other places. You can also capture countless pictures and keep them as a wonderful memory. 

Best Spots: Semgang, Phobjikha, Tingbitti, Yongola, Trongsa

Timings: Early morning and evening

Duration: As much as you want

Entry fee: No entry fee

Highlights: Enjoy birdwatching amidst the most beautiful nature’s scenery

29. Chele La Pass – A Gorgeous Area

Image Credit: Vinayaraj for Wikimedia Commons

The Chele La Pass is one of the highest motorable points in Bhutan. One of the best things to do in Bhutan is to bike to Chele La Pass, which is 4,000 metres above sea level and between the Haa and Paro valleys. It was built in the 1990s and has sharp turns with sheer drops. The journey to the pass is truly gorgeous. Flaunting the gorgeous vistas of Himalayan Mountains, this pass is no less than a paradise to witness the scenic charm of Bhutan. Here, you can also observe the white poppies which are covered on the mountain slopes. Also, admire the bloominh Rhododendrons that are sited around the pass. Along with admiring natural beauty of the place, you can also embark on hiking at this pass.

Location: On the Bondey-Haa Highway, Bhutan

Timings: 24 hours

Duration: 3-4 hours

Entry fee: No entry fee

Highlights: Enjoy gorgeous vistas of Himalayan Mountains

Related Post: Bhutan Hill Stations

30. Attending Nimalung Tsechu Festival- For A Delightful Experience

Image Credit: Vinayaraj for Wikimedia Commons

Bhutan is known for its fascinating culture, which represents its rich history. To witness the real essence of Bhutan, you can attend its Nimalung Tsechu Festival. The festival is celebrated in Bumthang and attracts tourists from all around the world. It is a festival where all the people of country come together to celebrate the rich culture of the country. It is a 10-day celebration where Bhutanese pay homage to various gods through vibrant dances and singing programs. People wear different attires and props specially for this festival. To experience a blissful experience and enjoy a sense of spiritually, attending the Nimalung Tsechu Festival is among the best things to do in Bhutan.

Location: Bumthang, Bhutan

Timings: In the month of June

Duration: 15 days from 21st June

Entry fee: NA

Highlights: Enjoy the festive vibe and witness the grand celebration of displaying rich culture of Bhutan.

31. Experience Staying In A Homestay- Explore Bhutanese Hospitality

Image Credit: BrokenSphere for Wikimedia Commons
When visiting Bhutan, book your stay in any homestay for a delightful staycation experience. All the homestays and their staff are welcoming and ready to offer your warm hospitality like never before. In these homestays, you can enjoy a glimpse of its local culture and can learn many amazing facts about culture and heritage of Bhutan. Relish home-cooked food that are prepared with organic ingredients and served with love and care. During your Bhutan trip, having an amazing stay experience in this homestay is among the top things to do in Bhutan. Enjoy a perfect retreat and soak in the amazing culture of Bhutan.

Best Spots: Namgay Homestay, Haa Valley Homestay, and Pari Village View Homestay

Timings: Open all day

Duration: Depends on your choice

Entry Fee: Depends on the homestay you choose

Highlights: Enjoy warm hospitality and home-cooked food in Bhutan

Related Post: Bhutan In Septemer

32. Shopping In Thimphu- Explore Bhutanese Goods

Image Credit: Gerd Eichmann for Wikimedia Commons

Buying in Thimphu, the pretty capital of Bhutan, is something unique as compared to the shopping done elsewhere, blending the best of both the ancient and the modern. There are many shops, markets, and handicraft shops selling all kinds of handmade products, from beautifully hand-woven fabrics to nicely crafted silver jewellery and masks that are a speciality in the Buddhist culture. The Handicrafts Emporium is one of the best places to indulge in the richness of Bhutanese crafts. Everything is there: thangkas – paintings in silk or cloth with designs supposed to depict various aspects of the teachings of Buddha and nicely crafted sculptures.

Best spots: Terton Gallery, Suvedi Enterprise, and The Artshop Gallery

Timings: Daytime

Duration: 4-5 hours

Entry fee: NA

Highlights: Explore many shops, markets, and handicraft shops selling all kinds of handmade products.

33. Witness Buddha Dordenma-The Largest Buddha Statue

Image Credit: אבנר אילנאי for Wikimedia Commons
If you are in Bhutan, don’t let Buddha Dordenma slip away from your itinerary. Renowned as one of the world’s largest Buddha statues, it is a wonderful architectural wonder that will surely offer a great retreat for your eyes and senses. The enormous bronze monument is covered in gold and is more than 50 meters tall. In addition, 125,000 more Buddha statues are housed there and arranged around the Buddha Dordenma statue. It shows how human faith manifests itself and how everyone can live in perpetual peace and happiness. It is thought that the idea was predicted as early as the eighth century in a holy artefact that Guru Padmasambhava preserved.

Location: Kuenselphodrang, Thimphu, Bhutan

Timings: 9 AM to 5 PM

Duration: 3-4 hours

Entry fee: Free

Highlights: Enjoy this wonderful architectural wonder that will surely offer a great retreat for your eyes and senses

Related Post: Monsoon In Bhutan

34. Dance with Monks- Rituals Of Bhutan

Image Credit: Sabine Blankevoort for Wikimedia Commons
Bhutan is a country deeply passionate about its festivals, and dancing is at the heart of these vibrant celebrations. In this Buddhist nation, even monks join in the joyous festivities, adding their own grace and fervor to traditional dances. During many festivals, monks from local monasteries and Dzongs (temple fortresses) come together to perform ritualistic dances that honor the occasion. If you’re lucky enough to visit a monastery during one of these festivals, you might even have the chance to join in the celebration—a truly unforgettable experience that adds a special dimension to your time in Bhutan.

You May Also Like To Read: Bhutan Villages

Bhutan is the kind of place where you’ll find hand-painted wall murals, crimson chilies drying in the sun, and cozy cafes wherever you go. Explore its vibrant culture as you indulge in your favorite activities in Bhutan. Trip to Bhutan and convince all your friends to tick off this destination from your bucket list. Wait no more, pack your bags, and get set go!

Frequently Asked Questions About Things To Do In Bhutan

What are the adventure activities to do in Bhutan?

Some of the must-do things in Bhutan include trekking, getting an insight into the history, exploring the various valleys, hiking, bird watching, visiting monasteries and temples, indulging in local food, shopping, trying out outdoor sports, and much more.

What is the best time to visit Bhutan?

The best time to pay a visit to Bhutan is anytime between March to May. During this time the valleys are at their full bloom, one can clearly witness Himalayan peaks, and enjoy trekking without any hindrances.

What are the top places to visit in Bhutan?

The top places to visit in Bhutan are Thimphu, Paro, Trongsa, Phuentsholing, Manas National Park, Jakar, Dochula, Laya, Jigme Dorji National Park, Trashiyangtse, Gasa, Mongar, and Lhuntse.

How many days should one spend in Bhutan?

For those who don’t have much time on their hands but still wish to witness the major landmarks of the country should visit Bhutan for at least 5 days minimum.

What is famous in Bhutan for shopping?

Bhutan is a hub for shopping. Some popular things to buy from this destination are handicrafts, silver jewelry, hand-woven textiles, wooden items, postal stamps, wooden bowls, Himalayan beads, and much more.

What should one eat in Bhutan?

The must-try food of Bhutan includes Ema datshi, Kewa datshi, Shamu datshi, Shakam ema datshi, Shakam paa, Shakam Shukam datshi, Phaksha paa, Sikam paa, and more.

What is Bhutan famous for?

There are many things that have led to Bhutan gain fame including the natural beauty, culture, heritage, forest conservation, biodiversity, and the humble crowds.
